g.text: total number of cases at which the KS test rejects the null hypothesis that observed and modeled dry spell
length distributions can be approximated with a Markov chain model at the monthly time scale. For
observation-based data sets, there are no cases of rejection in most of the regions while a few grid cells
located in Sahara, Northeast Brazil, and Southeast Asia have one to
ve cases of rejection out of
observation-based data sets indicating that the dry spell length distribution is not well presented with
Markov chain model in the respective regions. For model simulations, the spatial distribution of rejections
is similar to the observation-based estimates, with one to six cases out of 63 model simulations in the same
region, which in this case con
rms the reliability of the Markov chain assumption. At the annual time scale,
there were no cases of rejection for model simulations and less than 10 grid cells had one to two rejections
for observations (thus not shown in the
nite number of samples in the observed and modeled time
series at both time scales, and it is critical to assess whether this uncertainty substantially affects the model
validation results. To quantitatively assess the uncertainty due to
nite sample size, which also can be
referred to as statistical estimation error, we generate the uncertainty distribution of
bootstrapping (Basawa et al., 1990; Efron & Tibshirani, 1994). In each grid cell, 1,000 samples of binary time
series are generated through statistical simulation under Markov chain assumption (described in the previous
paragraph of this chapter) based on the
parameters estimated from the original time series.
then calculated for each statistical ensemble member, resulting in the uncertainty distribution for each
estimate from the observational data and the ensemble runs of the GCMs. The
the drought persistence error of ensemble
so that the uncertainty range of the estimated error can be spanned by the differences between boot-
strapped samples from the observations and the models.
To investigate the respective roles of the sources of uncertainty on the drought persistence error, we aim at
. For doing so, we adapt a methodology that has been previously used to par-
tition the spread in climate model projections (Hawkins & Sutton, 2009; Orlowsky & Seneviratne, 2013), with
cations that allow to account for observation uncertainty and the statistical estimation error of
Using an ANOVA-based approach, we aim to quantify the relative contribution of (i) differences among obser-
vational products, (ii) differences among climate models, (iii) internal climate variability, and (iv) statistical
. As ensemble members are subordinate to the mod-
els and bootstrapped samples are subordinate to the ensemble members and observations (Figure 4), we
apply a crossed and nested ANOVA (Krzywinski et al., 2014). A schematic of the partitioning is shown in
Assessment of the suitability of the Markov-chain assumption for approximating observed (a) and modeled (b) dry spell length distributions. Shown are the
number of cases at which a two-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov test rejects the null hypothesis that the observed (a) or modeled (b) dry spell length distribution
